title: Registry Performance & Lifecycle Audit
scope: registryManager.ts + base.ts + BaseRegistry.ts — initialization, caching, memory lifecycle

initialization.strategy: Dual-phase: CORE registries eager-loaded at startup, SECONDARY registries lazy-loaded on first access
initialization.concurrency_guard: Promise-based guard prevents concurrent initialization (base.ts line ~45)

caching.strategy: In-memory Map — entries persist for lifetime of process
caching.ttl: NONE — no TTL or cache invalidation mechanism
caching.eviction: NONE — entries never evicted once loaded

memory_estimate.tools: ~500+ entries × ~3KB each ≈ 1.5MB (CORE only; 13,967 ENHANCED would be ~42MB)

cross_registry_operations.performance_note: globalSearch does linear scan across all registries — acceptable for <50K total entries

findings.finding: Dual-phase initialization correctly prioritizes frequently-used registries
Promise-based concurrency guard prevents race conditions on lazy load
Idempotent loading ensures registries initialize exactly once
No TTL or cache invalidation — entries persist indefinitely. For MCP server (short-lived per request), this is acceptable. For long-running daemon mode, stale data risk.
If all ENHANCED layers load simultaneously, memory usage could reach ~50-60MB — may be excessive for constrained environments
Two base class patterns coexist (base.ts + BaseRegistry.ts) — should consolidate to one
globalSearch linear scan is O(n) across all entries — acceptable at current scale (<50K) but won't scale to 100K+

recommended_fixes.action: Add optional TTL to base.ts with configurable expiration (default: no expiry for MCP mode)
Consolidate base.ts and BaseRegistry.ts into single base class
recommended_fixes.reason: Two inheritance patterns creates confusion for new contributors
recommended_fixes.effort: ~2 sessions (many files reference one or the other)
